data.description: The rugged beauty of the Badlands draws visitors from around the world. These striking geologic deposits contain one of the world’s richest fossil beds. Ancient horses and rhinos once roamed here. The park’s 244,000 acres protect an expanse of mixed-grass prairie where bison, bighorn sheep, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets live today.

entranceFees.description: Fee covers the entry of a private vehicle and its occupants for 7 days
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Fee covers the entry of a motorcycle and its occupants for 7 days
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Fee covers the entry of an individual that is hiking, bicycling, etc... for 7 days
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Commercial sedan, 1 to 6 passenger capacity. $25 plus $15 per person - 7 days for Original Manifest
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Commercial van, 7 to 15 passenger capacity; $50 - 7 days for Original Manifest
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Minibus, 16 to 25 passenger capacity; $60 - 7 days for Original Manifest
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Motorcoach, 26 or more passenger capacity; $150 - 7 days for Original Manifest
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: This pass admits a single, private, non commercial vehicle and its occupants into the park. This pass does not include camping or give any type of discount at stores inside the park. Valid for one year from month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Badlands National Park is located 75 miles east of Rapid City, South Dakota. Physical Addresses for GPS* Park Headquarters: 25216 Ben Reifel Road, Interior, SD 57750. Northeast Entrance (I-90, Exit 131): 21020 SD Hwy 240, Interior, SD 57750. Pinnacles Entrance (I-90, Exit 110): 24240 Hwy 240, Wall, SD 57790. Interior Entrance: 20640 SD Hwy 377, Interior, SD 57750.

operatingHours.description: The park is open to visitors all year with the exception of weather closures.
operatingHours.name: Badlands National Park

images.title: Badlands Storm
images.altText: Layered badlands formations behind fields of green grass under cloudy and billowing clouds.
images.caption: Summer storms are frequently violent and unpredictable.

images.title: Badlands Yellow Mounds
images.altText: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.
images.caption: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.

images.title: Badlands Rugged Peaks
images.altText: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.
images.caption: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.

images.title: Clover Landscape
images.altText: Jagged badlands buttes extended in horizon amid yellow flowers under a blue sky.
images.caption: The park has seasonal changes in colors so plan ahead!

images.title: Badlands in the Winter
images.altText: road leading between snow covered badlands formations
images.caption: Winter in Badlands National Park often creates snow covered wonderlands throughout the park.

data.weatherInfo: The Badlands weather is variable and unpredictable with temperature extremes ranging from 116° F to -40° F. Summers are hot and dry with occasional violent thunderstorms. Hailstorms and occasional tornadoes can descend on the Badlands with sudden fury. Winters are typically cold with 12 to 24 inches of total snowfall.
data.name: Badlands

data.description: Immerse yourself in one of the longest caves in the world. With over 220 miles of mapped and surveyed passages, this underground wilderness appeals to human curiosity. Its splendor is revealed through fragile formations and glimpses of brilliant color. Its maze of passages lures explorers, and its scientific wealth remains a mystery. This resource is truly a jewel in the National Park Service.

emailAddresses.description: This email address connects online guests with staff at the visitor center. Every effort is made to respond to common questions and requests for information within 48 hours. However, some questions or requests for assistance may require input from other staff. In these instances, requests will be forwarded to the appropriate individual for a direct response.

data.directionsInfo: By car: Jewel Cave National Monument is located 13 miles west of Custer, South Dakota and 24 miles east of Newcastle, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 16. The monument is about 54 miles from Rapid City, South Dakota via U.S. Highway 16 / 385. By plane: The nearest major airport, Rapid City Regional Airport, is 63 miles away.

operatingHours.description: Jewel Cave National Monument is a day-use area and is available for outdoor recreation on a daily basis throughout the year. However, although the monument is normally open for surface activities year round, the visitor center, park store, and ranger-guided cave tours and operational hours vary from season to season. This means that the surface features and recreational areas are open year round, yet staffing levels and visitor services may be limited during the off-season.
operatingHours.name: Jewel Cave National Monument

images.title: Target Room
images.altText: The target room inside Jewel Cave.
images.caption: The target room inside Jewel Cave.

images.title: Hourglass Lake
images.altText: A cave explorer sits on some rocks and looks at a clear blue lake in Jewel Cave.
images.caption: Volunteer cave explorers discovered Hourglass Lake in October 2015, the first sizable body of water found within Jewel Cave.

images.title: Inner Sanctum
images.altText: A park ranger is standing on a metal platform within a long passageway with a vaulted ceiling.
images.caption: The Inner Sanctum is one of the longest and largest passageways along the Scenic Tour route, located near the Torture Room.

images.title: The Brain Drain
images.altText: A caver squeezes through a very small and tight opening, surrounded by multi-colored rocks.
images.caption: The Brain Drain is approximately eight inches high by 24 inches wide and is the tightest passage on the Wild Caving Tour.

images.title: The Heavenly Room
images.altText: A park ranger stands as a silhouette in a large room in Jewel Cave.
images.caption: The Heavenly Room is a large room along the Historic Lantern Tour within the historic entrance of Jewel Cave.

images.title: Nailhead Spar
images.altText: White-colored crystals with blunt tips sparkle against a black background.
images.caption: Calcite crystals, such as nailhead spar, cover most of the walls, ceilings, and floors within Jewel Cave.

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep
images.altText: A bighorn sheep ram stands in the highway, with a camper stopped in the other lane.
images.caption: Rocky mountain bighorn sheep are commonly seen within the monument, usually along Highway 16.

images.title: Red Squirrel
images.altText: A small red squirrel stands on a dead pine branch.
images.caption: Red squirrels are commonly observed along the Roof Trail near the visitor center.

images.title: Fall Season Foliage in Fog
images.altText: Fog filters through a stand of pine trees, with red and yellow foliage on the forest floor.
images.caption: Autumn is a beautiful time of year to visit the monument. The colors of fall are often the best during mid to late September.

images.title: Winter in the Pines
images.altText: Snow covers the ground and flocks pine trees.
images.caption: Although a "slower" time of year, the winter season offers some of the best scenery of the ponderosa pine forest.

images.title: Canyons Trail Descending toward the Historic Entrance
images.altText: A paved path with steps heads down a hillside, with rock overhangs and pine trees nearby.
images.caption: A portion of the Canyons Trail passes the historic entrance of Jewel Cave, with breathtaking views of nearby Hell Canyon.

images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Addresses an Audience
images.altText: A look-alike Theodore Roosevelt speaks to visitors on the patio of the visitor center.
images.caption: The monument hosts special events each summer, such as living history presentations of President Theodore Roosevelt.

images.title: The Ranger Cabin at Jewel Cave
images.altText: A small, dark-brown cabin sits on top of a hill with a walking path leading to its front porch.
images.caption: The original park ranger cabin, built during the 1930s, is available for public access during the summer and early fall seasons.

images.title: Visitor Center Exhibit Area
images.altText: A wall mural showing red-colored rock transitions into a room with a large cave map on the wall.
images.caption: The visitor center provides several engaging exhibits and displays about the resources within the monument.

images.title: Pasque Flowers in Bloom
images.altText: White to light purple flowers with yellow centers poke through pine needles.
images.caption: Jewel Cave is home to several species of wildflowers, such as the South Dakota State Flower - the pasque flower.

images.title: Bats at Jewel Cave
images.altText: A small brown bat rests on a red-orange colored rock.
images.caption: Nine species of bats live within Jewel Cave National Monument. At times, visitors may see bats outside the historic entrance.

data.weatherInfo: Weather in the Black Hills varies significantly throughout the year and may be drastically different from the northern hills to the southern hills. The temperatures listed are for average lows to average highs in the location of Custer, South Dakota. Spring ~ Temp. Range of 29°F to 53°F / Summer ~ Temp. Range of 54°F to 80°F / Fall ~ Temp. Range of 33°F to 58°F / Winter ~ Temp. Range of 14°F to 37°F The yearly average rain is 19 in., with May being the wettest month. The yearly average snow is 48 in.
data.name: Jewel Cave

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.title: Giant Springs
images.altText: Small waterfall with brown rocks and green moss
images.caption: Giant springs is a site along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Site located in Great Falls, Montana

images.title: Sunset at Missouri Headwaters State Park, Montana
images.altText: sun dips behind mountains. In the foreground and meandering river catches the light. Leafy trees sur
images.caption: Sunset over Missouri River headwaters

images.title: Biking the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
images.altText: Cyclist biking dirt path along riverfront. Leafy trees and wetlands habitat in distance.
images.caption: Cyclist along the riverfront along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail

images.title: Beacon Rock
images.altText: Water in the foreground with large conical rock on shore
images.caption: Beacon Rock along the Columbia River in Washington.

images.title: Park overlooking Ohio River in Wheeling, West Virginia
images.altText: Interpretive sign overlooking park and river in the background
images.caption: Lewis and Clark interpretive sign overlooking park and the Ohio River

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: During the Cold War, a vast arsenal of nuclear missiles were placed in the Great Plains. Hidden in plain sight, for thirty years 1,000 missiles were kept on constant alert; hundreds remain today. The Minuteman Missile remains an iconic weapon in the American nuclear arsenal. It holds the power to destroy civilization, but is meant as a nuclear deterrent to maintain peace and prevent war.
data.directionsInfo: Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located at three sites along a fifteen mile stretch of Interstate 90 in western South Dakota. The Visitor Center is located immediately north of I-90, exit 131. The two historic sites which make up the park are four miles (Launch Control Facility Delta-01) and 15 miles (Launch Facility Delta-09) from the Visitor Center. No public transportation systems serve the park.

operatingHours.description:
Visitors are invited to go inside the fenced compound and look down into the silo at a Minuteman missile in its historic state, protected by a glass viewing enclosure. A narrated ranger guided tour of Delta-09 is available year-round using your cell phone. Inclement weather may close this site on occasion.

***Please Be Aware***
The park will NOT be changing days of operation. The park will be open Tuesday-Saturday through the summer and winter seasons.
operatingHours.name: Delta-09 Missile Silo

operatingHours.description:
A recorded audio tour at Delta-01 is available for all visitors that guides you to the front gate of Delta-01. To enter the Delta-01 facility, visitors need to attend a ranger-guided tour. Due to the size of the elevator and the confined space underground, advance reservations are required and tours are limited to 6 visitors at a time. Inclement weather may close this site on occasion. 

***Please Be Aware***
The park will NOT be changing days of operation. The park will be open Tuesday-Saturday.
operatingHours.name: Delta-01 Launch Control Facility

images.title: Delta-09 enclosure
images.altText: Glass structure over the silo allows visitors to look down at the missile
images.caption: The glass enclosure allows visitors to view a Minuteman II missile in the silo.

images.title: Minuteman II Missile
images.altText: A cylindrical missile inside an underground silo.
images.caption: A Minuteman II nuclear missile remains on alert, representing the 1,000 missiles which kept a constant vigil during the Cold War.

images.title: A winter visit to Delta-09
images.altText: Two people are visible at the missile silo through a chain link fence
images.caption: A visit to the Delta-09 missile silo allows the opportunity to consider the role of these missile in America's defense during the Cold War.

images.title: Delta-01
images.altText: A brown building behind a tall fence with warning signs
images.caption: For thirty years, US Air Force staff monitored a flight of ten nuclear missiles at the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility.

images.title: "Thirty Minutes or Less"
images.altText: A large metal blast door with art of a Domino with a nuclear missile
images.caption: Behind this blast door is the control center where two missileers kept a constant watch over ten nuclear missiles.

images.title: Morale Art of the Cold War
images.altText: A painting of a nuclear missile bursting through a Soviet Flag
images.caption: Located next to the elevator, this painting served as a reminder to missileers who they were defending the United States against.

images.title: Nose-to-Nose with Armegeddon
images.altText: View down a silo at a nuclear missile
images.caption: Visitors can peer through the glass at a Minuteman II missile in the silo at Delta-09.

images.title: Night view of Delta-09
images.altText: Night view of the Delta-09 site
images.caption: Night view of the Delta-09 site

images.title: Minuteman Missile Visitor Center
images.altText: A modern building with a prominent glass clerestory dominates a prairie landscape at sunset
images.caption: The visitor center at sunset.

images.title: Cold War "Blast Door" art at Delta-01
images.altText: A view of a concrete wall with a painting and a blastdoor with art
images.caption: Morale art reminded missile officers who the enemy was during the Cold War

images.title: Park Ranger leads a tour in the underground control center
images.altText: A ranger talks to visitors next to electronic cabinets.
images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour in the underground control center

data.weatherInfo: Rapid weather changes are common in the western South Dakota area where Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot dry summers and bitterly cold winters. Wind is a constant on the Great Plains, winds in excess of 50 mph not uncommon. During the winter season, winds typically blow from the north-northwest and have been known to cause wind chills in excess of -40 degrees.
data.name: Minuteman Missile

data.description: Imagine a 100-mile stretch of North America's longest river, a vestige of the untamed American West. The Missouri National Recreational River is where imagination meets reality. Two free flowing stretches of the Missouri make up the National Park. Relive the past by exploring the wild, untamed and mighty river that continues to flow as nature intended.
data.directionsInfo: The National Park Service headquarters is located at 508 East Second Street in Yankton, South Dakota.

operatingHours.description: The entire park includes the 39-Mile District and 59-Mile District. Both districts are open 24 hours, seven days a week.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Aerial of Missouri River
images.altText: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.
images.caption: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.

images.title: Remains of a sunken steamboat in Missouri River.
images.altText: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.
images.caption: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.

images.title: View of Missouri River
images.altText: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day
images.caption: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day

images.title: Park trailer
images.altText: Park educational trailer
images.caption: Educational trailer with painted pictures

images.title: All alone with my canoe
images.altText: A canoe loaded with gear sits quietly on a sandy river bank with blue sky above.
images.caption: Get into nature by paddling the Missouri River.

data.weatherInfo: Rapid weather changes are common along the Missouri National Recreational River corridor. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot summers and cold winters. Sunshine is abundant, particularly in the summer months. Average annual rainfall is 25 inches. Thunderstorms can be dangerous and visitors should be prepared for them, especially from June until late August. Winter snowfall averages 34 inches annually.
data.name: Missouri

data.description: Majestic figures of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln, surrounded by the beauty of the Black Hills of South Dakota, tell the story of the birth, growth, development and preservation of this country. From the history of the first inhabitants to the diversity of America today, Mount Rushmore brings visitors face to face with the rich heritage we all share.

emailAddresses.description: Park information.  Due to the volume of inquiries there may be a delay in getting a response.

data.directionsInfo: Visitors traveling by car from the East use Exit 61 off I-90 follow signs. Coming from the West use exit 57 exit at Rapid City and follow U.S. Highway 16 southwest to Keystone and then Highway 244 to Mount Rushmore. Visitors coming from the south should follow Highway 385 north to Highway 244, which is the road leading to the memorial.

exceptions.name: Mount Rushmore grounds - October 1 through March 9

operatingHours.description: Weather permitting, the grounds at Mount Rushmore are open every day of the year.  The Information Center, Visitor Center, Gift Shop and Carvers' Cafe are open every day except December 25th.
operatingHours.name: Mount Rushmore grounds - early March through September 30

images.altText: Photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky with puffy clouds floating over.
images.caption: Photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky with puffy clouds floating over.

images.title: Mount Rushmore and the Avenue of Flags
images.altText: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.
images.caption: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.

images.title: Mount Rushmore Through the Trees
images.altText: Mount Rushmore viewed from a distance through ponderosa pine trees.
images.caption: Mount Rushmore viewed from a distance through ponderosa pine trees.

images.title: Closeup of Mount Rushmore
images.altText: Closeup photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky.
images.caption: Closeup photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky.

images.title: Mount Rushmore With Talus Slope

images.caption: Mount Rushmore above the talus slope, where rock removed from the mountain fell.

images.title: Mount Rushmore At Night
images.altText: Mount Rushmore illuminated under a darkening evening sky.
images.caption: Mount Rushmore illuminated under a darkening evening sky.

data.weatherInfo: Weather at Mount Rushmore can be highly variable in any season. Summer high temperatures range from 70 to 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Fall high temperatures range from 45 to 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter high temperatures range from 20 to 40 degrees Fahrenheit. Spring high temperatures range from 30 to 70 degrees Fahrenheit. July and August are the warmest months, December and January the coldest. March and April receive the most snow, while May and June receive the most rain.
data.name: Mount Rushmore

data.description: Wind Cave National Park protects two very different worlds - one deep within the earth, the other a sunlit world of many resources. Bison, elk, and other wildlife roam the rolling prairie grasslands and forested hillsides of one of America's oldest national parks. Below the remnant island of intact prairie sits Wind Cave, one of the longest and most complex caves in the world.
data.directionsInfo: Wind Cave National Park is located in South Dakota about 11 miles north of Hot Springs, or about 22 miles south of Custer, on US Highway 385. The park Visitor Center, where all cave tours begin, is approximately 1/2 mile west of the highway.

operatingHours.description:
The park is open all day, every day. Snow or severe weather can limit access to some areas of the park, especially in winter. Visitor Center hours and cave tour schedules vary throughout the year. 

Visit the park website or call 605.745.4600 for current conditions.
operatingHours.name: Wind Cave National Park

images.title: Bison cow and calf
images.altText: a bison cow and calf on the prairie
images.caption: Several hundred bison roam the rolling prairie of Wind Cave National Park.

images.title: Rankin Ridge view
images.altText: rolling hills of forest and prairie landscape
images.caption: Wind Cave National Park from Rankin Ridge, the park's highest point.

images.title: Boxwork
images.altText: criss-cross-patterned calcite fins of the cave feature boxwork
images.caption: Delicate fins of boxwork, a rare cave feature, in Elk's Room, Wind Cave.

images.title: Wind Cave explorer
images.altText: a caver with pads and helmet crawling in the cave
images.caption: Each summer, the Wild Cave Tour offers the chance to get up close and personal with Wind Cave.

images.title: Prairie Dogs
images.altText: two prairie dogs watch from their burrow
images.caption: Prairie dog sightings are common throughout the park's prairies.

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Highs range from 50-70°F with highly variable weather. Spring is the park's wettest season. Summer: Hot and generally dry with daytime temperatures regularly exceeding 80°F (27°C). Strong thunderstorms are common and can produce large hail and lightning. Fall: Generally dry with warm days and cool nights. Highs 50-60°F. Lows below freezing are common. Winter: Highs are in the high 30s with lows around 10°F. Snowfall averages 30 inches annually, periodically closing park roads.
data.name: Wind Cave
